William Shakespeare.action: Henslowe promotes a new play by Shakespeare as a crowd-pleaser with mistaken identities, a shipwreck, a pirate king, and love triumphant.
William Shakespeare.assessment: This suggests Shakespeare's work is seen as commercially viable and entertaining, indicating his competence in crafting appealing plays.

William Shakespeare.action: Henslowe insists the new play is by Shakespeare to convince Fennyman to invest.

William Shakespeare.action: The play is titled 'Romeo and Ethel the Pirate's Daughter,' a somewhat unusual and less refined title.

William Shakespeare.action: The play is described as a comedy with complex elements and crowd-pleasing features.

William Shakespeare.action: Practices his signature repeatedly, showing frustration and impatience with himself.

William Shakespeare.action: Practices his signature repeatedly, crumpling and tossing away each unsatisfactory attempt.

William Shakespeare.action: Practises his signature repeatedly, crumpling and tossing away each attempt in frustration.

William Shakespeare.action: Struggles with his boots while being pressed by Henslowe about the progress of his play.

William Shakespeare.action: Responds to Henslowe's urgent questioning with poetic language rather than direct answers.

William Shakespeare.action: Strides purposefully along the street despite the chaotic environment.

William Shakespeare.action: Acknowledges Henslowe's financial support and past patronage despite tension over money.

William Shakespeare.action: Asks Henslowe to lend him fifty pounds to become a partner in the Chamberlain's Men.

William Shakespeare.action: Turns down Henslowe's implied offer to lend money after Henslowe's emotional reaction.

William Shakespeare.action: Engages in a somewhat terse and transactional conversation with Henslowe about money and plays.

William Shakespeare.action: Negotiates with Henslowe about money owed and the plays he has written, showing awareness of his financial and professional situation.
William Shakespeare.assessment: This indicates a practical understanding of his career and finances, reflecting a degree of professional competence.

William Shakespeare.action: Asks Henslowe for fifty pounds to buy a partnership in the Chamberlain's Men, signaling ambition and strategic thinking about his career advancement.
William Shakespeare.assessment: This shows foresight and confidence in investing in his future, a clear sign of competence and self-assurance.

William Shakespeare.action: Turns down Henslowe's emotional appeal and refuses to accept money without clear terms.

William Shakespeare.action: Will gratefully makes a mental note of the Puritan preacher's harsh condemnation of the theatres and players.

William Shakespeare.action: Will goes to his weekly confession with Dr. Moth, an apothecary and seer, and lies on a couch to share his inner thoughts.

William Shakespeare.action: Will expresses a nostalgic lament about his lost ability to make love out of words and to inspire passion and connection.

William Shakespeare.action: Will seems unwilling to respond directly when Dr. Moth asks if he lies with women.

William Shakespeare.action: Will gratefully makes a mental note of the Puritan preacher's harsh condemnation of the theatres.

William Shakespeare.action: Will goes to Dr. Moth's house for a weekly confession and participates in a psychological session.

William Shakespeare.action: Will expresses doubt about his current creative abilities, lamenting that he once had the gift to make powerful, moving words but now feels diminished.

William Shakespeare.action: Describes his marriage to Anne Hathaway as distant and cold, mentioning a 'cold bed' and banishment as a blessing.

William Shakespeare.action: Admits to having lost his creative gift and being unable to love or write about love.

William Shakespeare.action: Uses vivid and imaginative metaphors to describe his creative block, such as 'trying to pick a lock with a wet herring' and 'the proud tower of my genius has collapsed.'
William Shakespeare.assessment: Despite his claimed loss of gift, his ability to articulate his condition with creative language suggests underlying skill and intelligence.

William Shakespeare.action: Will looks at the snake bangle in wonder and asks if it will restore his gift.
William Shakespeare.assessment: This shows a moment of vulnerability or uncertainty about his own creative abilities, suggesting some self-doubt rather than confident competence.

William Shakespeare.action: Will drops a sovereign into Dr. Moth's hand and takes the bracelet without hesitation.

William Shakespeare.action: Will walks straight past Henslowe and states his destination confidently: 'To the Palace at Whitehall.'
William Shakespeare.assessment: This demonstrates clear purpose and confidence in his movements and decisions, a positive indicator of competence.

William Shakespeare.action: Prithee, Mr. Kempe, break a leg. You too, good Crab.
William Shakespeare.assessment: Wishing good luck to fellow actors shows a friendly and supportive attitude.

William Shakespeare.action: Responds somewhat defensively when asked if he is writing.
William Shakespeare.assessment: Defensiveness may indicate insecurity or reluctance to share, suggesting some guardedness rather than openness.

William Shakespeare.action: Engages in casual banter with Burbage about money and roles.

William Shakespeare.action: Does not challenge Burbage's accusation of lying about payment.

William Shakespeare.action: Engages in casual, witty banter with Kempe and Burbage backstage, discussing plays and roles.

William Shakespeare.action: Mentions he is still owed money for the play, and negotiates with Burbage about joining the Chamberlain's Men only when he has fifty pounds.

William Shakespeare.action: Defensively nods when asked if he is writing a comedy, describing it as 'all but done, a pirate comedy, wonderful.'

William Shakespeare.action: Agrees to give Burbage two sovereigns and promises two more upon receiving the pages.

William Shakespeare.action: Carefully rolls up a piece of paper with his name and slips it into the mouth of the snake bangle.

William Shakespeare.action: Turns to see Henslowe approaching after negotiating with Burbage.

William Shakespeare.action: WILL slips a snake bracelet onto ROSALINE's arm during an intimate moment.

William Shakespeare.action: WILL expresses distraction and concern when hearing coughing from the audience, suggesting awareness of others' reactions.

William Shakespeare.action: WILL jokes about the audience coughing to disrupt his play.

William Shakespeare.action: Engages in a romantic moment with Rosaline but remains alert and distracted by the coughing audience.

William Shakespeare.action: Notices the coughing from the audience and comments on it wittily.

William Shakespeare.action: Mentions feeling a scene coming on while observing the play.

William Shakespeare.action: Distracted during an intimate moment by external noise.

William Shakespeare.action: Leaves the stage area abruptly when Henslowe points out Viola knows his play by heart.
William Shakespeare.assessment: This non-action or omission may indicate discomfort or avoidance, possibly reflecting insecurity or lack of confidence in social or professional interactions.

William Shakespeare.action: Writing furiously through the night, excited and pleased with his work, then eagerly sharing his new scene with Henslowe.
William Shakespeare.assessment: Shows passion and enthusiasm for his craft, which can be inspiring and engaging to others, indicating a positive and sincere nature.

William Shakespeare.action: Nearly knocking down Henslowe in his rush to leave the house, interrupting him mid-sentence.

William Shakespeare.action: Barging into Burbage's house and bedroom without ceremony or warning.

William Shakespeare.action: Expressing excitement and confidence in his work by proclaiming 'God, I'm good!'

William Shakespeare.action: Writing furiously through the night, producing about ten pages, and leaving his room like a man with a mission.

William Shakespeare.action: Brandishing the pages of his new work to Henslowe and confidently proclaiming 'God, I'm good!'
William Shakespeare.assessment: This shows self-assurance and pride in his work, reflecting confidence and a positive self-assessment of his skill, which are indicators of competence.

William Shakespeare.action: Barging into Burbage's house without ceremony and shouting for him.

William Shakespeare.action: Entering Burbage's bedroom abruptly and finding Rosaline in bed with the Master of the Revels, leaving him shattered.

William Shakespeare.action: Sits brooding alone after the auditions, reflecting on the situation.

William Shakespeare.action: Waits patiently outside the kitchen door after delivering his letter, despite being treated dismissively by the servant who throws dirty water near him.

William Shakespeare.action: Looks around the room searching for Thomas Kent and stops a passing servant to ask about him.

William Shakespeare.action: Expresses despair by telling Henslowe 'We are lost.'
William Shakespeare.assessment: While this shows anxiety, it also reveals honesty and openness about his feelings, which can be seen as sincere but not necessarily warm or cold.

William Shakespeare.action: Listens to Wabash's stuttering and muttering lines in agony and says to Henslowe, 'We are lost.'
William Shakespeare.assessment: This action shows a lack of confidence and a sense of despair about the performance, indicating self-doubt and anxiety rather than assured competence.

William Shakespeare.action: Shuts his eyes and prays backstage before the performance.
William Shakespeare.assessment: This suggests a reliance on hope or faith rather than control or preparation, reflecting nervousness and a lack of confident command over the situation.

William Shakespeare.action: Observes the performance and interacts with Henslowe, who reassures him despite uncertainty.
William Shakespeare.assessment: While Shakespeare shows concern, he also seeks reassurance and remains engaged, indicating some awareness of the stakes and a willingness to face challenges, though not with full confidence.

William Shakespeare.action: Encourages Sam Gosse nervously attempting a speech by saying 'Luck be with you, Sam.'
William Shakespeare.assessment: Will's encouragement shows a supportive and kind attitude toward a struggling actor, indicating warmth and goodwill.

William Shakespeare.action: Looks as if he would rather be dead when the Hemmings brothers perform poorly.
William Shakespeare.assessment: This reaction suggests frustration or disappointment but does not necessarily reflect unkindness; it may indicate high standards rather than lack of warmth.

William Shakespeare.action: Responds absently to Sam's nervous approach and poor performance.
William Shakespeare.assessment: Will's somewhat distracted and absent response could indicate a momentary lack of engagement or warmth, though it may be due to stress.

William Shakespeare.action: Encourages Sam Gosse nervously before the play begins, saying 'Luck be with you, Sam.'
William Shakespeare.assessment: This shows a supportive and confident attitude as a leader, indicating some competence in managing his actors despite underlying concerns.

William Shakespeare.action: Reacting with visible distress ('looks as if he would rather be dead') when Sam delivers his lines poorly.
William Shakespeare.assessment: This reaction suggests anxiety and a lack of control over the situation, reflecting a momentary lapse in confidence and composure.

William Shakespeare.action: Attempts to prompt Sam to perform better by asking him to recite a line.
William Shakespeare.assessment: This shows initiative and an attempt to salvage the situation, indicating problem-solving skills and engagement.

William Shakespeare.action: Accepts Henslowe's suggestion to continue the play despite the problem with Sam and the delayed entrance of Juliet.
William Shakespeare.assessment: This demonstrates practical decision-making under pressure and adaptability, key aspects of competence in a live theatre setting.

William Shakespeare.action: Asks 'How will it?' in response to Henslowe's uncertain reassurance about the play continuing.
William Shakespeare.assessment: This question reveals a desire for clarity and control, but also exposes uncertainty and lack of a concrete plan, indicating some insecurity.

William Shakespeare.action: Will has his hands over his ears, cowering in dread anticipation before Viola's entrance as Juliet.
William Shakespeare.assessment: This shows a vulnerable, human side to Will, indicating sensitivity and emotional openness, which can be seen as a warm, sincere reaction.

William Shakespeare.action: Will turns around in amazement at the sound of Viola's voice as Juliet.
William Shakespeare.assessment: His amazement and attention to Viola's performance suggest genuine appreciation and openness to others' talents, reflecting warmth and friendliness.

William Shakespeare.action: Has his back to the stage, hands over his ears, cowering in dread anticipation before Viola's entrance as Juliet.
William Shakespeare.assessment: This action suggests a lack of confidence and emotional control in a critical moment, indicating some insecurity or nervousness rather than assuredness.

William Shakespeare.action: Turns around in amazement at the sound of Viola's voice on stage.
William Shakespeare.assessment: This reaction shows a capacity for recognizing and appreciating a powerful performance, indicating perceptiveness and openness to unexpected talent, which is a positive indicator of artistic competence.

William Shakespeare.action: After the intense and tragic scene where 'Tybalt' kills 'Mercutio,' William Shakespeare stands breathless and faces Viola, sharing a moment of mutual, transfixed silence.
William Shakespeare.assessment: This moment of silent connection with Viola suggests a sincere and intimate emotional openness, indicating warmth through vulnerability and genuine engagement.

William Shakespeare.action: Delivers the intense and real performance of Romeo reacting to Mercutio's death, holding the audience spellbound and quiet.
William Shakespeare.assessment: This action demonstrates Shakespeare's skill and confidence as an actor and playwright, effectively conveying deep emotion and maintaining audience engagement.

William Shakespeare.action: Engages in a staged sword fight and 'kills' Tybalt, then immediately faces Viola while still breathless.
William Shakespeare.assessment: This shows physical capability and composure under pressure, as well as the ability to transition quickly from action to emotional connection, indicating strong stage presence and control.

William Shakespeare.action: Stares at Viola after learning she is married, remains silent and does not move, allowing the weight of the moment to settle.
William Shakespeare.assessment: Will's silence and stillness in response to Viola's unspoken truth shows a respectful and sensitive restraint, indicating a sincere and considerate nature.

William Shakespeare.action: Engages deeply in the shared performance with Viola, embodying Romeo and Juliet with emotional intensity and connection.
William Shakespeare.assessment: His immersion in the role and the emotional exchange with Viola reflects a capacity for empathy and genuine emotional expression, suggesting warmth in his interpersonal engagement.

William Shakespeare.action: Says farewell to Viola as Romeo, with a tone of sorrow and tenderness.
William Shakespeare.assessment: The sorrowful farewell conveys a heartfelt sincerity and emotional openness, which are positive indicators of warmth.

William Shakespeare.action: After the fight, stands breathless but faces Viola and asks directly, 'You are married?'
William Shakespeare.assessment: This shows a moment of emotional vulnerability but also a directness and presence of mind to confront a difficult truth, indicating moderate competence in handling tense interpersonal situations.

William Shakespeare.action: Remains motionless after Viola's silence, allowing the implication of her silence to fill the air.
William Shakespeare.assessment: This restraint and ability to hold a charged moment without rushing to fill the silence suggests emotional intelligence and control, reflecting competent self-regulation.

William Shakespeare.action: Turns away from Viola and begins to descend from the balcony, then stops when Viola speaks as Juliet.
William Shakespeare.assessment: This hesitation and responsiveness to Viola's cues show sensitivity and attentiveness, but also a slight uncertainty or lack of assertiveness in the moment.

William Shakespeare.action: As Romeo, seems unable to speak initially, then utters a brief farewell.
William Shakespeare.assessment: The initial inability to speak suggests a momentary loss of composure or confidence, which slightly undermines his competence, though he recovers to deliver his line.

William Shakespeare.action: Engages deeply in the role of Romeo, participating in the emotional exchange with Viola as Juliet, allowing time to seem to stop.
William Shakespeare.assessment: This immersion and ability to suspend reality indicate strong artistic skill and emotional intelligence, key aspects of his competence as a playwright and actor.

William Shakespeare.action: As Romeo, Will gives forty ducats to the apothecary despite the danger involved, saying 'I pay thy poverty and not thy will.'
William Shakespeare.assessment: This action shows generosity and empathy toward the apothecary's poverty, indicating a good-natured and sincere concern for others' wellbeing.

William Shakespeare.action: Will embraces Viola tenderly as Romeo embraces Juliet, sharing a moment of mutual tears and silent communication.
William Shakespeare.assessment: This intimate and sincere moment reveals Will's capacity for deep emotional connection and genuine affection, reflecting warmth and trustworthiness.

William Shakespeare.action: Performs the role of Romeo with emotional depth, especially in the scene embracing Juliet and sharing a tearful, intimate moment with Viola.
William Shakespeare.assessment: This action demonstrates Shakespeare's skill and confidence as an actor and his ability to convey complex emotions effectively, indicating strong competence in his craft.

William Shakespeare.action: Performs the final, emotionally charged scene of Romeo with conviction and skill, delivering the lines and dying on stage convincingly.
William Shakespeare.assessment: This action demonstrates Shakespeare's capability as an actor and playwright, showing his ability to engage the audience and convey deep emotion effectively.

William Shakespeare.action: Embraces and kisses Viola passionately in a private farewell on stage after the play's end.
William Shakespeare.assessment: This intimate and sincere display of affection shows Shakespeare's capacity for genuine emotional connection and warmth toward Viola.

William Shakespeare.action: Steps forward with Viola and the company to meet the audience's applause.
William Shakespeare.assessment: Acknowledging the audience and sharing the moment with his company reflects a friendly and inclusive nature.

William Shakespeare.action: Remains silent or passive during the arrest scene when Tilney accuses Viola of being a woman.
William Shakespeare.assessment: His lack of immediate defense or intervention for Viola in this tense moment may suggest a missed opportunity to protect or support her, indicating a lower level of warmth in this instance.

William Shakespeare.action: Writes and stages 'Romeo and Juliet' which ends with a powerful line and initially causes silence but then erupts into wild applause.
William Shakespeare.assessment: This demonstrates Shakespeare's skill and confidence as a playwright, able to craft a compelling and moving story that ultimately captivates the audience.

William Shakespeare.action: Engages in a passionate farewell with Viola on stage immediately after the play ends.
William Shakespeare.assessment: This shows emotional confidence and a willingness to blur personal and professional boundaries, which may be risky but also indicates boldness and control over the theatrical moment.

William Shakespeare.action: Remains composed and present with the company as the audience applauds and as the arrest unfolds.
William Shakespeare.assessment: Maintaining composure in a tense and unexpected situation suggests a level of confidence and situational awareness.

William Shakespeare.action: Does not intervene or react aggressively when Tilney arrests the company and accuses Viola of being a woman.
William Shakespeare.assessment: This omission could indicate either strategic restraint or a lack of immediate assertiveness; it is ambiguous but may suggest a momentary lapse in taking control of the situation.

William Shakespeare.action: The Queen of England herself acknowledges Master Shakespeare directly after the play, indicating his recognized status and presence in the theatrical world.
William Shakespeare.assessment: Being singled out by the Queen suggests that Shakespeare has achieved a notable level of skill and reputation, reflecting competence in his craft and social navigation.

William Shakespeare.action: Bows deeply to the Queen after she invites him to come as himself next time to Greenwich to speak more.
William Shakespeare.assessment: Bowing deeply is a respectful and sincere gesture, showing politeness and deference, which can be seen as a warm social behavior.

William Shakespeare.action: Bows deeply to the Queen after their conversation.
William Shakespeare.assessment: This action shows Shakespeare's awareness of courtly etiquette and his ability to comport himself appropriately in the presence of royalty, indicating social competence and confidence.

William Shakespeare.action: Engages in a meaningful exchange with the Queen, who invites him to come as himself next time to Greenwich for further conversation.
William Shakespeare.assessment: This suggests Shakespeare's skill in navigating high social circles and making a positive impression on influential figures, reflecting intellectual and social competence.

William Shakespeare.action: Does not interrupt or overstep during the Queen's interaction with others and her departure.
William Shakespeare.assessment: His restraint and patience in this social setting demonstrate emotional intelligence and self-control, which are aspects of competence.

William Shakespeare.action: Says to Viola, 'I have hurt you and I am sorry for it.'
William Shakespeare.assessment: Expressing apology shows self-awareness and concern for Viola's feelings, indicating sincerity and a capacity for warmth.

William Shakespeare.action: Refuses to write a comedy, saying 'A comedy! What will my hero be but the saddest wretch in the kingdom, sick with love?'
William Shakespeare.assessment: His harsh dismissal of the Queen's command and the comedic genre suggests bitterness and a lack of openness or tolerance at this moment.

William Shakespeare.action: Engages in a collaborative and imaginative conversation with Viola about the play's characters and plot.
William Shakespeare.assessment: Despite his bitterness, he participates in a creative exchange with Viola, showing a willingness to connect and share ideas, which reflects some warmth and friendliness.

William Shakespeare.action: Says 'I am done with theatre. The playhouse is for dreamers. Look where the dream has brought us.'
William Shakespeare.assessment: This statement reveals disillusionment and withdrawal, indicating a moment of emotional coldness or distancing from others.

William Shakespeare.action: Expresses deep emotional pain and disillusionment with theatre, saying 'I am done with theatre. The playhouse is for dreamers. Look where the dream has brought us.'
William Shakespeare.assessment: This shows a moment of self-doubt and emotional vulnerability, which may indicate a temporary lapse in confidence and professional resolve.

William Shakespeare.action: Engages in a creative brainstorming session with Viola, developing the outline of a new play (Twelfth Night) despite his bitterness.
William Shakespeare.assessment: Despite his emotional turmoil, Will demonstrates intellectual agility and creative skill by collaborating on plot and character ideas, indicating strong competence in his craft.

William Shakespeare.action: Responds harshly to the idea of writing a comedy, calling his hero 'the saddest wretch in the kingdom, sick with love.'
William Shakespeare.assessment: This reaction shows a certain rigidity and emotional bias that may limit his openness to new ideas, suggesting a slight lack of adaptability.

William Shakespeare.action: Catches on quickly to Viola’s plot suggestions, such as the heroine dressing as a boy and being unable to declare her love.
William Shakespeare.assessment: This quick grasp of narrative elements and ability to build on ideas reflects sharp intellectual and creative competence.

William Shakespeare.action: Admits uncertainty about how the story ends, saying 'I don't know...'
William Shakespeare.assessment: This admission of not knowing the ending shows intellectual humility and openness, which can be a positive trait in creative competence, though it also reveals a current lack of resolution.

William Shakespeare.action: Will and Viola share a deep, sincere moment, expressing timeless love and a promise that they will never age or fade for each other.
William Shakespeare.assessment: This moment reveals Will's capacity for deep emotional connection and sincere affection, indicating warmth through his loving and tender expression.

William Shakespeare.action: Will watches Viola leave after their farewell kiss, quietly observing her departure.
William Shakespeare.assessment: Will's silent watching suggests a respectful and tender farewell, showing warmth in his gentle acceptance of parting without bitterness or anger.

William Shakespeare.action: Will writes the story of Viola as a heroine with a soul greater than the ocean and a spirit stronger than the sea's embrace.
William Shakespeare.assessment: By elevating Viola as a heroic and noble figure in his writing, Will demonstrates admiration and reverence, reflecting warmth through his sincere appreciation and idealization of her character.

William Shakespeare.action: Will quietly begins writing 'Twelfth Night' inspired by Viola's story.
William Shakespeare.assessment: This act shows Will's creative devotion and emotional investment in telling Viola's story, indicating warmth through his dedication to honoring her through art.

William Shakespeare.action: Sits at his table and begins writing 'Twelfth Night' with a clear vision of the story and characters inspired by his experience with Viola.
William Shakespeare.assessment: This action demonstrates William Shakespeare's ability to channel personal experience into creative work, showing skill, focus, and confidence in his craft.

William Shakespeare.action: Expresses deep emotional connection and inspiration from Viola, leading to the creation of a heroine for all time.
William Shakespeare.assessment: This indicates emotional intelligence and the capacity to transform feelings into enduring artistic output, reflecting competence in both emotional and creative domains.

William Shakespeare.action: After Viola leaves, he watches her go silently without attempting to stop her or express further feelings.
William Shakespeare.assessment: This omission might suggest a lack of assertiveness or confidence in personal matters, potentially indicating a momentary lapse in social or emotional competence.
